question: Question_B_04_(b)
statement:
Let a={[}1,2,-1{]}. Consider the transformation
$T:\mathbb{R}^3\to\mathbb{R}^3$ defined by
$T(\mathbf{x})=\mathbf{x}\times\mathbf{a}$ for all \textbf{x} in
$\mathbb{R}^3$, where $\times$ is the cross-product in $\mathbb{R}^3$.

Find the matrix A that corresponds to T.
sols:
The columns of a linear transformation matrix, \emph{A}, are populated
by the transformed vectors of each of the basis vectors. In this case
the first column of \emph{A} will be $[1,0,0]\times\mathbf{a}$, the
second, $[0,1,0]\times\mathbf{a}$, and the third,
$[0,0,1]\times\mathbf{a}$. By computing these cross products, we get,

\begin{align*}
\left[1,0,0\right]\times\mathbf{a}=[1,2,-1]&=[0,1,2]\\
\left[0,1,0\right]\times\mathbf{a}=[1,2,-1]&=[-1,0,-1]\\
\left[0,0,1\right]\times\mathbf{a}=[1,2,-1]&=[-2,1,0]
\end{align*}

Therefore the linear transformation matrix \emph{A} which corresponds to
\emph{T} is,

\[A=
\begin{bmatrix}
0  &  -1  &  -2\\
1  &  0   &  1\\
2  &  -1  &  0
\end{bmatrix}\].

\emph{Notice if we wanted some sort of confirmation of our answer we can
pick a random vector, say \textbf{x}={[}3,4,7{]}, compute
$\mathbf{x}\times\mathbf{a}$ and compute A\textbf{x} and make sure they
are the same thing.}

\[[3,4,7]\times[1,2,-1]=[-18,10,2]\]

\emph{and}

\[A
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2\\
-1
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
-18\\
10\\
2
\end{bmatrix}\]

\emph{which is indeed the same result.}
hints:
Recall that we can formulate the matrix by understanding how the
transformation affects the basis vectors.
